message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: CAMEL: Communicative Agents for "Mind" Exploration of Large Language Model Society
Paper Abstract: The rapid advancement of chat-based language models has led to remarkable progress in complex task-solving. However, their success heavily relies on human input to guide the conversation, which can be challenging and time-consuming. This paper explores the potential of building scalable techniques to facilitate autonomous cooperation among communicative agents, and provides insight into their "cognitive" processes. To address the challenges of achieving autonomous cooperation, we propose a novel communicative agent framework named role-playing. Our approach involves using inception prompting to guide chat agents toward task completion while maintaining consistency with human intentions. We showcase how role-playing can be used to generate conversational data for studying the behaviors and capabilities of a society of agents, providing a valuable resource for investigating conversational language models. In particular, we conduct comprehensive studies on instruction-following cooperation in multi-agent settings. Our contributions include introducing a novel communicative agent framework, offering a scalable approach for studying the cooperative behaviors and capabilities of multi-agent systems, and open-sourcing our library to support research on communicative agents and beyond: https://github.com/camel-ai/camel.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Here are the search results for "Multi-agent systems":

## Definition
A multi-agent system (MAS) is a computerized system composed of multiple interacting intelligent agents.(no content)Multi-agent systems can solve problems that are difficult or impossible for an individual agent or a monolithic system to solve.

## Key Characteristics
Agents in multi-agent systems have important characteristics including autonomy (being at least partially independent and self-aware) and decentralization (no agent is designated as controlling).(no content)Multi-agent systems can manifest self-organisation and other complex behaviors even when the individual strategies of all their agents are simple.

## Composition and Types of Agents
Multi-agent systems consist of agents and their environment, and while multi-agent systems research typically refers to software agents, the agents could equally well be robots, humans or human teams.

## Applications
Applications where multi-agent systems research may deliver an appropriate approach include online trading, disaster response, target surveillance and social structure modelling.

## Recent Development
With advancements in large language models (LLMs), LLM-based multi-agent systems have emerged as a new area of research, enabling more sophisticated interactions and coordination among agents.

Links: [{"title":"Category:Multi-agent systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Multi-agent_systems"},{"title":"Multi-agent system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_system"},{"title":"Distributed multi-agent reasoning system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_multi-agent_reasoning_system"},{"title":"Autonomous Agents and Multi-Agent Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_Agents_and_Multi-Agent_Systems"},{"title":"International Conference on Autonomous Agents and Multiagent Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Conference_on_Autonomous_Agents_and_Multiagent_Systems"},{"title":"Template:Multi-agent system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Template:Multi-agent_system"},{"title":"Multi-agent reinforcement learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_reinforcement_learning"},{"title":"// - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jason_(multi-agent_systems_development_platform)"},{"title":"Java Agent Development Framework - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Java_Agent_Development_Framework"},{"title":"Consensus dynamics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consensus_dynamics"}]

Here are the search results for "Multi-agent systems":

## Definition
A multi-agent system (MAS) is a computerized system composed of multiple interacting intelligent agents.(no content)Multi-agent systems can solve problems that are difficult or impossible for an individual agent or a monolithic system to solve.

## Key Characteristics
Agents in multi-agent systems have important characteristics including autonomy (being at least partially independent and self-aware) and decentralization (no agent is designated as controlling).(no content)Multi-agent systems can manifest self-organisation and other complex behaviors even when the individual strategies of all their agents are simple.

## Composition and Types of Agents
Multi-agent systems consist of agents and their environment, and while multi-agent systems research typically refers to software agents, the agents could equally well be robots, humans or human teams.

## Applications
Applications where multi-agent systems research may deliver an appropriate approach include online trading, disaster response, target surveillance and social structure modelling.

## Recent Development
With advancements in large language models (LLMs), LLM-based multi-agent systems have emerged as a new area of research, enabling more sophisticated interactions and coordination among agents.

Web search results for query: "Large language models"

Links: [{"title":"Wikipedia:Large language models - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Large_language_models"},{"title":"Large language model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Large_language_model"},{"title":"Category:Large language models - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Large_language_models"},{"title":"Wikipedia talk:Large language models - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia_talk:Large_language_models"},{"title":"List of large language models - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_large_language_models"},{"title":"Wikipedia talk:Large language models/Archive 1 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia_talk:Large_language_models/Archive_1"},{"title":"Language model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Language_model"},{"title":"Wikipedia talk:Writing articles with large language models/Archive 1 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia_talk:Writing_articles_with_large_language_models/Archive_1"},{"title":"1.58-bit large language model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1.58-bit_large_language_model"},{"title":"Llama (language model) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LLaMA"}]

Here are the search results for "Large language models":

## Overview

A large language model (LLM) is a language model trained with self-supervised machine learning on a vast amount of text, designed for natural language processing tasks, especially language generation.(no content)The largest and most capable LLMs are generative pre-trained transformers (GPTs) and provide the core capabilities of modern chatbots.

## Key Characteristics

LLMs consist of billions to trillions of parameters and operate as general-purpose sequence models, generating, summarizing, translating, and reasoning over text.(no content)LLMs can be fine-tuned for specific tasks or guided by prompt engineering.(no content)These models acquire predictive power regarding syntax, semantics, and ontologies inherent in human language corpora, but they also inherit inaccuracies and biases present in the data they are trained on.

## Capabilities and Impact

LLMs represent a significant new technology in their ability to generalize across tasks with minimal task-specific supervision, enabling capabilities like conversational agents, code generation, knowledge retrieval, and automated reasoning that previously required bespoke systems.

## Recent Developments

Since 2023, many LLMs have been trained to be multimodal, having the ability to also process or generate other types of data, such as images, audio, or 3D meshes. These LLMs are also called large multimodal models (LMMs), or multimodal large language models (MLLMs).

Vogel - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Armorica_(game)"},{"title":"Sociality - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sociality"},{"title":"Competitive altruism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Competitive_altruism"}]

I've completed a web search for "Cooperative behavior" and found comprehensive information about this topic. Here are the key findings:

## Definition and Overview

In evolution, cooperation is the process where groups of organisms work or act together for common or mutual benefits.(no content)It is commonly defined as any adaptation that has evolved, at least in part, to increase the reproductive success of the actor's social partners.

## Scope Across Species

Cooperation exists not only in humans but in other animals as well. The diversity of taxa that exhibits cooperation is quite large, ranging from zebra herds to pied babblers to African elephants.(no content)Various cetacean species have been documented engaging in cooperative behavior. Bottlenose dolphins, orcas, and humpback whales are among the species that have been observed foraging cooperatively in the wild.

## Types and Mechanisms

Mutualism is a form of symbiosis that is beneficial to both involved organisms. Mutualism has many forms and can occur when the benefits are immediate or deferred, when individuals exchange beneficial behaviors in turn, or when a group of individuals contribute to a common good.(no content)Certain studies have suggested that fairness affects human cooperation; individuals are willing to punish at their own cost (altruistic punishment) if they believe that they are being treated unfairly.

## Game Theory Perspective

In game theory, a cooperative or coalitional game is a game with groups of players who form binding "coalitions" with external enforcement of cooperative behavior (e.g. through contract law).

The search results provide substantial information about the evolutionary, biological, psychological, and mathematical dimensions of cooperative behavior.

Links: [{"title":"Agent-based model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agent-based_model"},{"title":"Comparison of agent-based modeling software - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comparison_of_agent-based_modeling_software"},{"title":"Agent-based social simulation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agent-based_social_simulation"},{"title":"Agent-based model in biology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agent-based_model_in_biology"},{"title":"Agent-based modeling - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/?title=Agent-based_modeling&redirect=no"},{"title":"Swarm (simulation) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swarm_(simulation)"},{"title":"GAMA Platform - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/GAMA_Platform"},{"title":"Repast (modeling toolkit) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Repast_(modeling_toolkit)"},{"title":"Joshua M. Epstein - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joshua_M._Epstein"},{"title":"Agent-based computational economics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agent-based_computational_economics"}]

## Search Results for "Agent-based Modeling"

I found comprehensive information about agent-based modeling. Here are the key findings:

### Definition and Core Concept

An agent-based model (ABM) is a computational model for simulating the actions and interactions of autonomous agents (both individual or collective entities such as organizations or groups) in order to understand the behavior of a system and what governs its outcomes.(no content)Agent-based models are a kind of microscale model that simulate the simultaneous operations and interactions of multiple agents in an attempt to re-create and predict the appearance of complex phenomena.

### Emergence and Complexity

The process is one of emergence, which some express as "the whole is greater than the sum of its parts", where higher-level system properties emerge from the interactions of lower-level subsystems.

### Key Components

Most agent-based models are composed of: (1) numerous agents specified at various scales (typically referred to as agent-granularity); (2) decision-making heuristics; (3) learning rules or adaptive processes; (4) an interaction topology; and (5) an environment.

### Implementation and History

ABMs are typically implemented as computer simulations, either as custom software, or via ABM toolkits, and this software can be then used to test how changes in individual behaviors will affect the system's emerging overall behavior.(no content)The idea of agent-based modeling was developed as a relatively simple concept in the late 1940s. Since it requires computation-intensive procedures, it did not become widespread until the 1990s.

### Applications

Agent-based modeling has been applied across various domains including biology, social science, economics, and urban planning, with applications ranging from modeling disease spread and traffic patterns to studying economic markets and ecological systems.

## Search Results for "Agent-based Modeling"

I found comprehensive information about agent-based modeling. Here are the key findings:

### Definition and Core Concept

An agent-based model (ABM) is a computational model for simulating the actions and interactions of autonomous agents (both individual or collective entities such as organizations or groups) in order to understand the behavior of a system and what governs its outcomes.(no content)Agent-based models are a kind of microscale model that simulate the simultaneous operations and interactions of multiple agents in an attempt to re-create and predict the appearance of complex phenomena.

### Emergence and Complexity

The process is one of emergence, which some express as "the whole is greater than the sum of its parts", where higher-level system properties emerge from the interactions of lower-level subsystems.

### Key Components

Most agent-based models are composed of: (1) numerous agents specified at various scales (typically referred to as agent-granularity); (2) decision-making heuristics; (3) learning rules or adaptive processes; (4) an interaction topology; and (5) an environment.

### Implementation and History

ABMs are typically implemented as computer simulations, either as custom software, or via ABM toolkits, and this software can be then used to test how changes in individual behaviors will affect the system's emerging overall behavior.(no content)The idea of agent-based modeling was developed as a relatively simple concept in the late 1940s. Since it requires computation-intensive procedures, it did not become widespread until the 1990s.

### Applications

Agent-based modeling has been applied across various domains including biology, social science, economics, and urban planning, with applications ranging from modeling disease spread and traffic patterns to studying economic markets and ecological systems.

Web search results for query: "Conversational AI"

Links: [{"title":"Chatbot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chatbot"},{"title":"Conversational user interface - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conversational_user_interface"},{"title":"Conversational commerce - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conversational_commerce"},{"title":"Conversable - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conversable"},{"title":"Jabberwacky - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jabberwacky"},{"title":"ChatGPT - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ChatGPT"},{"title":"Amelia (company) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amelia_(company)"},{"title":"Gupshup - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gupshup"},{"title":"List of chatbots - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_chatbots"},{"title":"Language creation in artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Language_creation_in_artificial_intelligence"}]

Here are the search results for "Conversational AI":

## Overview

A conversational user interface (CUI) is a user interface for computers that emulates a conversation with a human.(no content)Conversational interfaces use natural language processing (NLP) to allow computers to understand, analyze, and create meaning from human language.

## Key Technologies

Modern chatbots use generative artificial intelligence systems that are capable of maintaining a conversation with a user in natural language and simulating the way a human would behave as a conversational partner.(no content)AI chatbots typically use a foundational large language model, such as GPT-4 or the Gemini language model, which is fine-tuned for specific uses.

## Types of Conversational Interfaces

There are two main categories of conversational interfaces: voice assistants and chatbots. A voice user interface allows a user to complete an action by speaking a command, with Apple's Siri being one of the first voice assistants widely adopted, introduced in October 2011.

## Business Applications

Companies are leveraging chatbots as a way to offload simple questions and transactions from human agents. These chatbots provide the option to assist a user, but can directly transfer the customer to a live agent within the same chat window if the conversation becomes too complex.

## Recent Examples

Chatbots have increased in popularity as part of the AI boom of the 2020s, and the popularity of ChatGPT, followed by competitors such as Gemini, Claude and later Grok.

Web search results for query: "Prompt engineering"

Links: [{"title":"Prompt engineering - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prompt_engineering"},{"title":"Retrieval-augmented generation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Retrieval-augmented_generation"},{"title":"Talk:Prompt engineering - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Prompt_engineering"},{"title":"Prompt injection - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prompt_injection"},{"title":"Prompt - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prompt"},{"title":"Wikipedia:Articles for deletion/Vibe coding - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Articles_for_deletion/Vibe_coding"},{"title":"Prompt criticality - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prompt_criticality"},{"title":"Wikipedia:Signs of AI writing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Signs_of_AI_writing"},{"title":"Engineering - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Engineering"},{"title":"Sydney (Microsoft) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sydney_(Microsoft)"}]

Based on the web search results, here's what I found about prompt engineering:

## Overview

Prompt engineering is the process of structuring or crafting an instruction in order to produce better outputs from a generative artificial intelligence (AI) model.(no content)It typically involves designing clear queries, adding relevant context, and refining wording to guide the model toward more accurate, useful, and consistent responses.

## What is a Prompt?

A prompt is natural language text describing the task that an AI should perform.(no content)A prompt for a text-to-text language model can be a query, a command, or a longer statement including context, instructions, and conversation history.

## Techniques and Applications

Prompt engineering may involve phrasing a query, specifying a style, choice of words and grammar, providing relevant context, or describing a character for the AI to mimic.(no content)When communicating with a text-to-image or a text-to-audio model, a typical prompt is a description of a desired output such as "a high-quality photo of an astronaut riding a horse" or "Lo-fi slow BPM electro chill with organic samples".

## History and Significance

After the release of ChatGPT in 2022, prompt engineering was soon seen as an important business skill, albeit one with an uncertain economic future.(no content)A comprehensive 2024 survey of the field identified over 50 distinct text-based prompting techniques and around 40 multimodal variants, demonstrating rapid diversification in prompting strategies.

For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.
